--- title: "Regression and Statistical Inference" --- # 1. ::: {.cell hash='03_regression_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_128d22639b944e4f333169a3028fb117'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(dplyr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> Warning: Paket 'dplyr' wurde unter R Version 4.3.2 erstellt ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> #> Attache Paket: 'dplyr' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:stats': #> #> filter, lag ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` #> Die folgenden Objekte sind maskiert von 'package:base': #> #> intersect, setdiff, setequal, union ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Read data car_prices <- readRDS("../../assignment_data/car_prices.rds") # check dimensions dimensions <- dim(car_prices) # Print the number of rows and columns cat( "Number of Rows : ", dimensions[1], "\n", "Number of Columns : ", dimensions[2], "\n" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> Number of Rows : 181 #> Number of Columns : 22 ``` ::: ::: # 2. **Detailed Look at the data** ::: {.cell hash='03_regression_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_27e4dc90d3e78cff72e787355fd6dd52'} ```{.r .cell-code} # overview with head() function head(car_prices) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # quick summary summary(car_prices,digits = 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> aspiration doornumber carbody drivewheel #> Length:181 Length:181 Length:181 Length:181 #> Class :character Class :character Class :character Class :character #> Mode :character Mode :character Mode :character Mode :character #> #> #> #> enginelocation wheelbase carlength carwidth carheight #> Length:181 Min. : 86.6 Min. :141 Min. :60.3 Min. :47.8 #> Class :character 1st Qu.: 94.5 1st Qu.:166 1st Qu.:64.0 1st Qu.:52.0 #> Mode :character Median : 96.5 Median :173 Median :65.4 Median :53.7 #> Mean : 98.2 Mean :173 Mean :65.7 Mean :53.6 #> 3rd Qu.:100.4 3rd Qu.:180 3rd Qu.:66.5 3rd Qu.:55.5 #> Max. :120.9 Max. :208 Max. :72.3 Max. :59.8 #> curbweight enginetype cylindernumber enginesize #> Min. :1488 Length:181 Length:181 Min. : 61 #> 1st Qu.:2122 Class :character Class :character 1st Qu.: 98 #> Median :2410 Mode :character Mode :character Median :120 #> Mean :2521 Mean :127 #> 3rd Qu.:2910 3rd Qu.:141 #> Max. :4066 Max. :326 #> fuelsystem boreratio stroke compressionratio #> Length:181 Min. :2.54 Min. :2.07 Min. : 7.00 #> Class :character 1st Qu.:3.15 1st Qu.:3.08 1st Qu.: 8.50 #> Mode :character Median :3.31 Median :3.23 Median : 9.00 #> Mean :3.32 Mean :3.23 Mean : 8.85 #> 3rd Qu.:3.59 3rd Qu.:3.40 3rd Qu.: 9.40 #> Max. :3.94 Max. :4.17 Max. :11.50 #> horsepower peakrpm citympg highwaympg price #> Min. : 48 Min. :4200 Min. :13.0 Min. :16.0 Min. : 5118 #> 1st Qu.: 70 1st Qu.:4800 1st Qu.:19.0 1st Qu.:25.0 1st Qu.: 7609 #> Median : 95 Median :5200 Median :24.0 Median :30.0 Median : 9980 #> Mean :106 Mean :5182 Mean :24.8 Mean :30.5 Mean :12999 #> 3rd Qu.:116 3rd Qu.:5500 3rd Qu.:30.0 3rd Qu.:34.0 3rd Qu.:16430 #> Max. :288 Max. :6600 Max. :49.0 Max. :54.0 Max. :45400 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # data types: cat("Data Types:\n", sapply(car_prices, class), "\n") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> Data Types: #> character character character character character numeric numeric numeric numeric numeric character character numeric character numeric numeric numeric numeric numeric numeric numeric numeric ``` ::: ::: **How do numbers differ from strings regarding their data type?** \ Numeric data in R can take the form of either integers or floating-point numbers, and they are primarily employed for mathematical calculations and numerical analysis. Conversely, strings represent character data, comprising sequences of characters that can include letters, digits, and symbols. In some cases, datasets may include categorical variables, which can be converted into numerical values using methods such as factorization with functions like as.factor(). # 3. **Run a linear regression. You want to explain what factors are relevant for the pricing of a car.** \ Using the lm() function, ::: {.cell hash='03_regression_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_01d63c143d5cfb6599c6c6ca95f17bd7'} ```{.r .cell-code} lm_all <- lm(price ~ .,data = car_prices) summary(lm_all, digits = 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -5662 -1120 0 798 9040 #> #> Coefficients: #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) -36269.965 15460.866 -2.346 0.020354 * #> aspirationturbo 1846.206 1041.391 1.773 0.078386 . #> doornumbertwo 242.523 571.929 0.424 0.672172 #> carbodyhardtop -3691.743 1424.825 -2.591 0.010561 * #> carbodyhatchback -3344.335 1238.359 -2.701 0.007757 ** #> carbodysedan -2292.820 1356.014 -1.691 0.093043 . #> carbodywagon -3427.921 1490.285 -2.300 0.022885 * #> drivewheelfwd -504.564 1076.623 -0.469 0.640030 #> drivewheelrwd -15.446 1268.070 -0.012 0.990299 #> enginelocationrear 6643.492 2572.275 2.583 0.010806 * #> wheelbase -30.197 92.776 -0.325 0.745294 #> carlength -29.740 51.672 -0.576 0.565824 #> carwidth 731.819 244.533 2.993 0.003258 ** #> carheight 123.195 134.607 0.915 0.361617 #> curbweight 2.612 1.781 1.467 0.144706 #> enginetypedohcv -8541.957 4749.685 -1.798 0.074219 . #> enginetypel 978.748 1786.384 0.548 0.584619 #> enginetypeohc 3345.252 933.001 3.585 0.000461 *** #> enginetypeohcf 972.919 1625.631 0.598 0.550462 #> enginetypeohcv -6222.322 1236.415 -5.033 1.43e-06 *** #> cylindernumberfive -11724.540 3019.192 -3.883 0.000157 *** #> cylindernumberfour -11549.326 3177.177 -3.635 0.000387 *** #> cylindernumbersix -7151.398 2247.230 -3.182 0.001793 ** #> cylindernumberthree -4318.929 4688.833 -0.921 0.358545 #> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209 4196.494 -2.650 0.008946 ** #> enginesize 125.934 26.541 4.745 5.00e-06 *** #> fuelsystem2bbl 177.136 883.615 0.200 0.841400 #> fuelsystemmfi -3041.018 2576.996 -1.180 0.239934 #> fuelsystemmpfi 359.278 1001.529 0.359 0.720326 #> fuelsystemspdi -2543.890 1363.546 -1.866 0.064140 . #> fuelsystemspfi 514.766 2499.229 0.206 0.837107 #> boreratio -1306.740 1642.221 -0.796 0.427516 #> stroke -4527.137 922.732 -4.906 2.49e-06 *** #> compressionratio -737.901 555.960 -1.327 0.186539 #> horsepower 10.293 22.709 0.453 0.651035 #> peakrpm 2.526 0.634 3.983 0.000108 *** #> citympg -90.352 166.647 -0.542 0.588538 #> highwaympg 154.858 167.148 0.926 0.355761 #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.9415, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9264 #> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 ``` ::: ::: Examining the summary, we can identify variables with low p-values, indicating their relevance to car pricing. Notably, factors such as peakrpm, stroke, enginesize, cylindernumber, and enginetype exhibit high relevance, as their p-values are substantially low, below 0.001. In contrast, features like carwidth and carbody show a comparatively lower impact on car prices, with p-values ranging between 0.001 and 0.01.The remaining regressors demonstrate a diminished influence on determining the car price. # 4. Let's examine the regressor "peakrpm." According to the summary, it is of numeric data type, ranging between 4200 to 6600. \ The linear regression model provides a positive but modest estimate for "peakrpm." This suggests that as the value of the regressor increases, the car price tends to increase, although not substantially. Specifically, for every one-unit increase in peakrpm, the car price increases by only 2.526 units. However, since the value of "peakrpm" varies in magnitudes of 1000, it can lead to changes in the car price on a similar scale.\ What's noteworthy is that "peakrpm" holds statistical significance due to its low p-value. This indicates a strong relevance in determining the car's price. # 5. ::: {.cell hash='03_regression_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_1fe105641c2de65f80bf150bfb3b3c31'} ```{.r .cell-code} car_prices2 <- car_prices %>% mutate(seat_heating = TRUE) model <- lm(price ~ ., data = car_prices2) summary(model) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> #> Call: #> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices2) #> #> Residuals: #> Min 1Q Median 3Q Max #> -5662 -1120 0 798 9040 #> #> Coefficients: (1 not defined because of singularities) #> Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) #> (Intercept) -36269.965 15460.866 -2.346 0.020354 * #> aspirationturbo 1846.206 1041.391 1.773 0.078386 . #> doornumbertwo 242.523 571.929 0.424 0.672172 #> carbodyhardtop -3691.743 1424.825 -2.591 0.010561 * #> carbodyhatchback -3344.335 1238.359 -2.701 0.007757 ** #> carbodysedan -2292.820 1356.014 -1.691 0.093043 . #> carbodywagon -3427.921 1490.285 -2.300 0.022885 * #> drivewheelfwd -504.564 1076.623 -0.469 0.640030 #> drivewheelrwd -15.446 1268.070 -0.012 0.990299 #> enginelocationrear 6643.492 2572.275 2.583 0.010806 * #> wheelbase -30.197 92.776 -0.325 0.745294 #> carlength -29.740 51.672 -0.576 0.565824 #> carwidth 731.819 244.533 2.993 0.003258 ** #> carheight 123.195 134.607 0.915 0.361617 #> curbweight 2.612 1.781 1.467 0.144706 #> enginetypedohcv -8541.957 4749.685 -1.798 0.074219 . #> enginetypel 978.748 1786.384 0.548 0.584619 #> enginetypeohc 3345.252 933.001 3.585 0.000461 *** #> enginetypeohcf 972.919 1625.631 0.598 0.550462 #> enginetypeohcv -6222.322 1236.415 -5.033 1.43e-06 *** #> cylindernumberfive -11724.540 3019.192 -3.883 0.000157 *** #> cylindernumberfour -11549.326 3177.177 -3.635 0.000387 *** #> cylindernumbersix -7151.398 2247.230 -3.182 0.001793 ** #> cylindernumberthree -4318.929 4688.833 -0.921 0.358545 #> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209 4196.494 -2.650 0.008946 ** #> enginesize 125.934 26.541 4.745 5.00e-06 *** #> fuelsystem2bbl 177.136 883.615 0.200 0.841400 #> fuelsystemmfi -3041.018 2576.996 -1.180 0.239934 #> fuelsystemmpfi 359.278 1001.529 0.359 0.720326 #> fuelsystemspdi -2543.890 1363.546 -1.866 0.064140 . #> fuelsystemspfi 514.766 2499.229 0.206 0.837107 #> boreratio -1306.740 1642.221 -0.796 0.427516 #> stroke -4527.137 922.732 -4.906 2.49e-06 *** #> compressionratio -737.901 555.960 -1.327 0.186539 #> horsepower 10.293 22.709 0.453 0.651035 #> peakrpm 2.526 0.634 3.983 0.000108 *** #> citympg -90.352 166.647 -0.542 0.588538 #> highwaympg 154.858 167.148 0.926 0.355761 #> seat_heatingTRUE NA NA NA NA #> --- #> Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #> #> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared: 0.9415, Adjusted R-squared: 0.9264 #> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF, p-value: < 2.2e-16 ``` ::: ::: Since all the values in the "seat_heating" variable are the same (TRUE), it implies there is no variability in that variable, and this lack of variability doesn't influence the dependent variable. Intuitively, the estimate value should have been zero due to this perfect collinearity. However, the function returns NA for all the parameters because of the singularity.
